Source: pubchem | Source description: Norfentanyl | C14H20N2O | CID 259381 - structure, chemical names, physical and chemical properties, classification, patents, literature, biological activities, safety/hazards/toxicity information, supplier lists, and more.

                    Text: 
                    Norfentanyl

PubChem CID

259381

Structure

Norfentanyl_small.png

Norfentanyl_3D_Structure.png

Chemical Safety

Irritant

Laboratory Chemical Safety Summary (LCSS) Datasheet

Molecular Formula

C14H20N2O

Synonyms

Norfentanyl

1609-66-1

N-phenyl-N-(piperidin-4-yl)propionamide

Propanamide, N-phenyl-N-4-piperidinyl-

N-phenyl-N-4-piperidinylpropionamide

Molecular Weight

232.32 g/mol

Computed by PubChem 2.2 (PubChem release 2025.04.14)

Dates

Create:

2005-03-26

Modify:

2025-04-19

Description

Norfentanyl is a monocarboxylic acid amide resulting from the formal condensation of the aryl amino group of 4-(N'-phenyl)piperidin-4-amine with propanoic acid. A major metabolite of fentanyl. It has a role as an opioid analgesic and a drug metabolite. It is an anilide, a member of piperidines and a monocarboxylic acid amide.


                    Context: 
                    This section provides a high-level summary of Norfentanyl, including its PubChem CID, molecular structure images, chemical safety classification, molecular formula and weight, key synonyms, dates of entry and modification, and a concise chemical and pharmacological description. Positioned at the top of the compound page, it serves as a summary box that introduces Norfentanyl before the more detailed sections on properties, identifiers, hazards, metabolism, and related data found throughout the rest of the document.

                    Text: 
                    N-phenyl-N-(piperidin-4-yl)propionamide is a DEA Schedule II controlled substance. Substances in the DEA Schedule II have a high potential for abuse which may lead to severe psychological or physical dependence. It is a Immediate precursors substance.

Controlled Substances Act Schedule

Immediate precursors

8 Pharmacology and Biochemistry

8.1 Metabolism / Metabolites

Norfentanyl is a known human metabolite of fentanyl.

9 Safety and Hazards

9.1 Hazards Identification

9.1.1 GHS Classification

Pictogram(s)

Irritant

Signal

Warning

GHS Hazard Statements

H302 (89.6%): Harmful if swallowed [Warning Acute toxicity, oral]

H315 (89.6%): Causes skin irritation [Warning Skin corrosion/irritation]

H319 (91.7%): Causes serious eye irritation [Warning Serious eye damage/eye irritation]

H335 (10.4%): May cause respiratory irritation [Warning Specific target organ toxicity, single exposure; Respiratory tract irritation]

Precautionary Statement Codes

P261, P264, P264+P265, P270, P271, P280, P301+P317, P302+P352, P304+P340, P305+P351+P338, P319, P321, P330, P332+P317, P337+P317, P362+P364, P403+P233, P405, and P501

(The corresponding statement to each P-code can be found at the GHS Classification page.)

ECHA C&L Notifications Summary


                    Context: 
                    This section provides information on norfentanyl’s presence as a human metabolite, specifying its localization within the kidney, liver, and cytoplasm, followed by detailed safety and hazard data. It outlines the GHS (Globally Harmonized System) classification for norfentanyl, including pictograms, hazard warnings, specific hazard and precautionary statements, and summarizes regulatory notifications, situating this content within the broader document’s coverage of norfentanyl’s biological activity, toxicology, and regulatory status.

                    (The corresponding statement to each P-code can be found at the GHS Classification page.)

ECHA C&L Notifications Summary

Aggregated GHS information provided per 48 reports by companies from 8 notifications to the ECHA C&L Inventory. Each notification may be associated with multiple companies.

Information may vary between notifications depending on impurities, additives, and other factors. The percentage value in parenthesis indicates the notified classification ratio from companies that provide hazard codes. Only hazard codes with percentage values above 10% are shown. For more detailed information, please visit ECHA C&L website.

9.1.2 Hazard Classes and Categories

Acute Tox. 4 (89.6%)

Skin Irrit. 2 (89.6%)

Eye Irrit. 2 (91.7%)

STOT SE 3 (10.4%)
